title: platinum jubilee how majesty celebrated
story: Platinum Jubilee: How Her Majesty celebrated Jubilees during  years on throneFrom the Silver Jubilee back in  to her Golden Jubilee in  and the joyous Diamond Jubilee of , millions of patriotic Brits have taken to the streets for Union Jack festooned tea partiesQueen Elizabeth on the Royal Jubilee tour of Scotland in  Image: MirrorpixByClaire OBoyleAssistant Features Editor Writer:,  Feb |comments This year, the Queen will become the first British monarch to celebrate a Platinum Jubilee after  years on the throne.To mark this historic achievement, people theand breadth of Britain are being urged to help throw the biggest ever thank-you party for our beloved Queen, who turns  in April. But Sunday, June , won’t be the first time the streets have been adorned with banners and bunting to celebrate Her Majesty’s long and glorious reign. From the Silver Jubilee back in  to her Golden Jubilee in  and the joyous Diamond Jubilee of , millions of patriotic Brits have taken to the streets for Union Jack-festooned tea parties, spirit-lting street parades and large-scale celebrations and raised a toast – sometimes in a chintzy themed glass – to Elizabeth II. With another right royal knees-up on the way, we look back at highlights from jubilees of the past…  And with iconic merchandise from chintzy mugs adorned with pictures of the Queen, regal tea towels and flag-stamped side plates, there’s nothing not to love about a Jubilee. With another right royal knees-up on the way, here are some of the highlights from the Queen’s Jubilees of yore. Silver Jubilee,  As many as  million people partied in the streets to mark the Queen’s  years on the throne. Thousands of events were organised across the country, with , held in London alone. The Royals kicked off the weekend of nationwide celebrations with a glittering trip to the Royal Opera House in London’s Covent Garden for a spectacular Silver Jubilee Gala in May .  Crowds of Londoners and tourists reflected the goodwill of the nation as they cheered for the radiant monarch, who donned a tiara and sparkling jewels for the occasion. The official celebrations began days later on June  when the Queen lit a beacon at Snow Hill, Windsor, watched by , onlookers. It sparked a chain of  set aglow bonfires around Britain.Crowds cheered as the Queen arrived in an open-top Land Rover along with Prince Philip and her two youngest sons, followed by Prince Charles, Princess Anne and husband Captain Mark Phillips.A torch was also lit to be flown to Australia, where it would spark a chain of , bonfires Down Under. Elsewhere, thousands partied on the Mall. The next day, vast crowds gathered to see the Queen drive in the gold state coach to St Paul’s cathedral for a service of thanksgiving attended by heads of state from around the world and former prime ministers of the UK. As well as street parties across the country, complete with Union Jack bunting and trestle tables by the dozen, patriotic punters got behind the horse-loving monarch at the Epsom Derby with a frenzy of flutters on Royal Plume and Lucky Sovereign. Golden Jubilee,  Street parties were thrown in Britain and around the world as far away as the Antarctic as millions of royal fans celebrated the Queen’s first  years on the throne. Tables lined a street in Devon for two miles and one partygoer in Bristol spent three days painting a ft Union Jack on her house.  At a party in Jubilee Street in Stepney, East London,  residents enjoyed a multicultural celebration, while in Coronation Avenue, Gateshead, another  revellers gathered to mark the occasion. More than  street parties in Bristol ran alongside another  events organised by the council, and in Marlborough, Wilts, , chairs were laid out for a giant tea party. Jubilee fever swept beyond Britain, with servicemen and women also celebrating as far away as Afghanistan. In London, a Party at the Palace marked the Golden Jubilee on June .  An audience of , – including teenage Princes Harry and William – watched in the gardens of Buckingham Palace. Another million watching on giant screens outside as they waved their Union Jacks in jubilation. At home a TV audience of around  million tuned in to watch a multitude of stars. The celebrities performing included Brian May of rock group Queen, Sir Elton John, Sir Paul McCartney, Atomic Kitten, Ozzy Osbourne and Tom Jones.  Diamond Jubilee,  Up and down the country an estimated six million revellers celebrated  years’ reign with street gatherings and tea parties. Prince Charles and we Camilla made a surprise visit to a party in Piccadilly, taking pride of place at a giant picnic table, while , people sat down to lunch. Rain meant lots of parties for the event – dubbed the Big Lunch – were moved indoors, with a Birmingham event winding up in the city’s cathedral.  In London, a flotilla of , boats took to the river as part of the Thames Diamond Jubilee Pageant. Around . million people lined the banks to cheer them on. Buckingham Palace partied once again, with thousands gathering on The Mall and in royal parks, while millions watched at home. Sir Elton John and Sir Paul McCartney performed on stage, joined by Dame Shirley Bassey, JLS and Kylie Minogue. Gary Barlow masterminded the event and performed along with Cheryl, while Robbie Williams delivered a raucous Let Me Entertain You. Comic Rob Brydon got lots of laughs while Prince Charles became emotional on stage, calling Her Majesty ‘Mummy’.  Events finished with a service of thanksgiving at St Paul’s Cathedral – which Prince Philip missed as he was in hospital with a bladder infection – and a Royal appearance on the balcony of Buckingham Palace. As the Red Arrows put on a stunning display, the crowd sang God Save the Queen. story: Prince George’s godmother shares how she gives him hilarious gts in tribute to DianaPrince George gets hilarious and noisy gts from his godmother Julia Samuel who is carrying on the tradition started by his late grandmother Princess DianaPrince George of Cambridge Image: Getty ImagesByLaura SharmanNews Reporter:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb |commentsPrince Georgeaposs godmother has shared how she gets funny presents for the future king in a tribute to Princess Diana. Julia Samuel, who was friends with Diana, said the late princess started the tradition that the godparent should buy a gt for the children that was the most hilariously inconvenient and dficult to make.She shared her memories of the eccentric tradition in an episode of the podcast How to Fail with Elizabeth Day. “So I do to George what [Diana] did to us... which is give impossible toys which are really noisy, take a lot of making, she said. “I come in slightly tipped by the size of the present that William then has to spend days putting together and then put all the machinery together. It makes awful tooting noises and lights flashing and all of that. That makes me laugh and it makes George laugh.”Ms Samuel spoke about how much Diana would have loved her grandchildren Prince George, Princess Charlotte and Prince Louis.The godmother, , said the young prince is amazing and that it is heartbreaking for all of them. “He’s funny and feisty and cheeky and God [Diana] would have loved him so much. That is heartbreaking for all of them,” she added.Ms Samuel, who is one of Prince George’s seven godparents, used to work in publishing before training as a counsellor, reports the Express.She met Diana at a dinner party in  and helped create Child Bereavement UK in .  The godmother received an MBE in  and now works as a bereavement counsellor in the paediatrics department at St Mary’s Hospital Paddington. Royal expert Katie Nicholl believes Prince William and Kate are careful when it comes to the presents they buy their children, despite living a le of privilege. She told OK! magazine: “George enjoys his iPad at school, both he and Charlotte are quite tech-savvy and, like most children, there probably are technical gadgets and such like on their wish list.  “Iaposm sure theyaposre not going to want for anything, but when it comes to technology and screens, they are careful not to spoil them with extravagant gting.” She added: “If it is something that happens to be a computer game or something like that then they are cautious of screen time so it could be a more practical gt.”It follows reports that the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge are wanting to move from London to Windsor. The couple made Kensington Palace their official home along with their three children after marrying in . news uk-news queen-sparkling-form-jokes-guests-"Queen cuts cake marking -year reignByTony JonesLaura ElstonDanya Bazaraa:,  Feb |comments The Queen was on sparkling form as she laughed and joked at a celebratory reception on the eve of her Platinum Jubilee. The monarch, just hours away from becoming the first British sovereign to reach a historic  years on the throne, joined members of the local community in the ballroom of Sandringham House to mark her milestone.Yvonne Browne, vice-president and chairman of the Sandringham WI, described the Queen as being on sparkling form. The event was the largest in-person public engagement the Queen had attended since before her recent health scare in mid October. The -year-old head of state arrived at the event with a wooden walking stick she rested on sagely as she leant forward to chat to the visitors. The guests were seated around tables waiting for a tea to be served but stood up respectfully to chat to the Queen. Wearing an Angela Kelly wedgwood blue crepe with white brocade dress, the Queen, who beamed with delight throughout, also carried her trademark black handbag. She cut a cake decorated with the Jubilee emblem to begin her Platinum year. Among the guests were members of the Sandringham branch of the Womenaposs Institute, Sandringham Estate pensioners and representatives from two local charities West Norfolk Befriending and Little Discoverers. The Queen also met former cookery school student Angela Wood who helped to perfect the famous dish coronation chicken served to guests after the Queenaposs  Coronation ceremony. Mrs Wood made the Queen laugh when she told the monarch she spent days and days altering it for Constance Spry and Rosemary Hume.  Commenting on how the recipe for coronation chicken has likely developed over the years the Queen told Angela Wood: Itaposs probably changed because in those days we did some things quite dferently. Shaun Mason, a junior sous chef, had created tiny bite size morsels of the coronation chicken, chicken with curry spices, apricot in a savoury tartlet, and he carried a tray of his creations into the ballroom and announced they were available to sample. As the morsels were placed between the Queen and Mrs Wood to try, the room erupted with laughter when the Queen quipped Iaposll go away, she turned to add: You can tell mewhen I come back. On October , the Queen held a Windsor Castle evening reception for delegates for the Global Investment Summit. But the next day she cancelled a two day trip to Northern Ireland, was secretly admitted to hospital for preliminary tests, before being put under doctorsapos orders to rest and only carry out light duties.  Before the pandemic the Queen would visit her WI colleagues at West Newton village hall every year as part of her winter stay on her Sandringham estate in Norfolk. The Queenaposs Platinum Jubilee will be celebrated across the country during an extended June Bank Holiday in honour of a monarch who has left an indelible mark on the le of the nation. But February , the date of the Queenaposs accession to the throne, is a poignant period for the Queen, as it is the day her father King George VI died in . She is already the nationaposs longest reigning monarch, and the longest still-serving sovereign in the world. During the reception the Queen also met representatives from West Norfolk Befriending a charity which aims to reduce the social isolation experienced by the elderly by matching them with trained volunteer befrienders who visit on a regular basis.  And she spoke to members of Little Discoverers which provides early education for pre-school children with movement dficulties and delayed development. When the Queen was presented with a copy of a Loyal Address written by primary schoolchildren from West Norfolk the head of state gave a frank opinion on public proclamations she has heard during her long reign. The Queen seemed to approve of the words from the younger generation who said about the Queen: You have shown a caring manner, determination, and dedication to help other people. We think youaposre doing a great job! We are very lucky to have had you as our Queen for so long. We are proud of you for helping us through this pandemic with your inspirational words, and by your actions setting a good example, especially as the last year has been so hard for you. After reading the address, on display in the ballroom, the Queen said to laughter from the guests: Most addresses are usually pompous...this is so much nicer.  The afternoon reception which the Queen clearly enjoyed ended with the cutting of an iced Victoria Sponge with the Platinum Jubilee logo as its decoration. Lady Dannatt, the Lord-Lieutenant of Norfolk, told the Queen the cake was turned upside for the benefit of the press photographs and the quipped to laughter I donapost matter  When it came to cutting the large cake the Queen thinking aloud said: Iaposll put the kne in, seeit works and she drove the kne in vertically and left it place adding somebody  can finish it off. title: alien spotted watching mars rover
story: Alien spotted watching Mars rover in certain proof of le, expert claimsA UFO expert claims they have found irrefutable proof that aliens exist, as they spotted a being with a pink body in images released by NASA of the Mars rover on the red planetScott C. Waring, a UFO expert, believes this could be an alien le-form Image: ufosightingsdailyByJohn BettAudience WriterKirsty CardReporter:,  Feb |comments A UFO expert believes they have spotted an alien watching the Mars rover in photos released by NASA.Scott C. Waring said the sighting was  per cent proof of intelligent le, and described the being as about a aposfoot-tallapos with a pink body.Analysing the pictures on his blog UFO Sightings Daily, Waring claimed to have found the figure among rocks on the surface of the Red Planet, as the Daily Star reports.The original image was uploaded by Nasa in April  but was found by Waring on February , , and it appears to show the alien laying in a relaxed pose, similar to Kate Winslet in Titanic. There are even footprints behind the person leading up to the location they chose to lay down at.Meanwhile, a woman says that she is having daily encounters with aliens after she spotted her first UFO during lockdown. title: i ate icelands frozen slimming
story: I ate Icelands frozen Slimming World meals for a week - this is what happenedManchester Evening News reporter Dianne Bourne dined on Icelands frozen Slimming World meals for a whole week to find out how effective they were, and the results are inDianne Bourne tried Icelands Slimming World ready meals to find outthey worked Image: MENByJohn BettAudience WriterDianne Bourne:,  Feb |comments With the year still being young and New Years Resolutions still ringing in our ears, many people around the country will still be trying to stick to their diet and exercise regimes. But dieting can be tough, and who has the time to plan out dferent healthy meals for each day of the week  Now, Iceland has you covered. The frozen food giant has teamed up with Slimming World to sell a series of meals that are designed to help you lose weight, but are they any good  Intrepid journalist Dianne Bourne, from the Manchester Evening News, has now put her tastebuds on the line as she dined out on seven meals from the range - and documented the effect on her weight loss.What do you think of the frozen Slimming World meals  Let us know in the comments... Day Chicken tikka and rice lunch bowl - £. Dianne said: A great way to kick off the week of taste tests - with one of the lunch bowl meals - designed, as the title suggests, as a lighter daytime option. This is a new one to the range and I enjoyed what was a satisfying mix of crunchy vegetables, rice and tasty tikka-coated chicken pieces which was also pretty filling. Rating:   Chicken carbonara - £.  Dianne said: I was not holding out much hope for this one as it smelt slightly unpleasant as it cooked away in the microwave. Billed as a aposcomforting pasta dish with seared chicken, smoky pork strips, mushroom and spinach in a white sauceapos it did not look all that inspiring or comforting when I poured it into my dish. There were around eight pieces of chicken and a few strips of pork, and my first thought was that it seemed to taste very salty and the consistency was a bit gloopy. For me, I think Iaposd rather stick with making my own carbonara - as the Slimming World versionis a fairly simple and much cheaper recipe to make from scratch. Rating:    Day  Caullower and chick pea dahl - £. Dianne said: This can be eaten on its own or as a side dish. It probably would have been better as a side dishIaposm honest as I found it a bit unfulfilling as a lunch dish. It had a pleasant curry hit though and I like the crunch of the caullower with the chickpeas. Rating:   Chilli Con Carne - £.  Dianne said: A really hearty dish with large chunks of meat in a rich sauce and the rice was nicely herbed up. If you werenapost doing Slimming World youaposd think this was just a regular chilli ready meal, which is probably the best compliment I can give it. Indeed, my friendaposs strapping -year-old lad aposaccidentallyapos microwaved himself one of these and gave it a big thumbs up as well, so itaposs definitely good in the aposgenerous portionapos stakes. Rating:   Day  Cowboy hotpot - £.  Dianne said: Itaposs safe to say this was the dish I was most looking forward to. I mean, it has cowboy in its title and sausages and potato in it so whataposs not to love  Well, unfortunately the dish itself was what I could not learn to love. It said on the packet it was best cooked in the oven and I followed the cooking times to the tee, but it came out very dry and stodgy. It just did nothing for me at all - the sausages were firm and dry and the potatoes also had a powdery consistency on top. So disappointed with this one, definitely not a yee-ha moment from me. Rating:   Beef vindaloo - £.  Dianne said: However, tea time well and truly gave me one of the highlights of the week - in the new beef vindaloo dish. This was a real treat. A really brilliant hit of spices in a rich tomato sauce with flavoursome lumps of beef. Rating:   Day  Moroccan style chicken soup - £. Dianne said: Again, a very off-putting smell from the microwave, but once cooked this one was pretty delicious. A really interesting spice mix with a decent amount of heat, and lots of pulled chicken which made this one a warming and filling soup dish that I would definitely buy again. Rating:   Beef Lasagne - £.  Dianne said: This one has been a favourite of many SW-ers for a while now, but theyaposve just introduced a new recipe. So it is as good as the old one  Well, I was pretty excited about this one - because itaposs even better. The new recipe has finally nailed the elusive creamy cheesy aspect of the lasagne that is not easy to do.  Taking a nosy at the recipe card on the inside, it appears to be a mixture of butternut squash, potato and the magic Quark that has created the delightful crispy cheesy topping here. A word of warning on this one though - while it can be cooked in the microwave, it does say for best results stick in the oven. And, while it does take a mammoth  minutes, it tastes sooo much better this way to get that cheesy crunch. Rating:    Day  Naked beef burrito - £. Dianne said: A good amount of spice kick in this one, and itaposs quite a satisfying lunch pot. If you have your HEA of cheese available I feel like it would be nicer with this mixed in - I added some peppers and salad on the side. Rating:   Hunteraposs chicken - £.  Dianne said: This one has to be cooked in the oven and is a large portion for two, so my other half got roped into eating this one with me. It had a long cooking time of over an hour this one - and Iaposm not surethataposs why the chicken was a bit dry and chewy. And oneaposs thing for sure, it looked absolutely nothing like the glossy image on the packaging when it came out of my oven. But the overall flavour was ok - although the barbecue sauce was a tad on the watery side. My feeling is this one would be much easier and better to simply recreate yourself at home - itaposs just a rasher of bacon plonked on some chicken really. Rating:    Day  Colcannon Mash - £ Dianne said: Running a bit out of options at this stage, I decide to try the colcannon mash which I team with steamed broccoli and salmon. The mash is, like a lot of the meals, a tad on the salty side but teams well with salmon and I like that you can taste the cabbage in the mash mix. This is a convenient one to have in the freezer for those moments you canapost be bothered making your own mash. Rating:   Smoky meatball tray bake with potato wedges - £  Dianne said: The meatballs were on the dry side, but had a decent flavour punch, and were extremely pleasant when mushed together with all the smoky tomato and chickpea sauce. There was a decent size portion for two of us, although we did add lots of vegetables for speed. This was a really tasty one - but Iaposm afraid it canapost get full marks this one for the sheer faff factor. It took hr and mins to cook in the oven which comes in very low on the convenience factor - as does the vast size of the packet that I needed to try and wodge in my not very sizeable freezer. Itaposs also pretty expensive for this style of dish. Rating:   Day  Slimming World chips - £. Dianne said: Itaposs the last day, so Iaposm going all out with the curry and chips on the menu. And thereaposs literally nothing  left to eat. So I bung some of the frozen chips in the oven and serve them with some baked beans. Now with these frozen chips, people either love them or hate them from my experience at Slimming World group.  I have personally perfected a good flavour by sprinkling some syn-free spice on them and then spraying them with low-calorie spray. They do have a slightly strange consistency, but they are a convenient option to have ready-made in the freezer when you canapost face peeling and chopping up potatoes and cooking from scratch. Rating:   Chicken tikka rogan josh - £.  Dianne said: Ending the week on a high with this classic curry. The Slimming World chicken tikka masala has been a bit of a staple since the Iceland range was first launched, but this new rogan josh version might even trump it for me. Loved the spice on this one, and the added lumps of tomato and pepper. You could almost be eating a aposrealapos takeaway curry. Rating:   Did it work  Dianne said: Well, this is the big question isnapost it  After a whole week of eating the ready meals, and sticking  per cent to the Slimming World plan throughout the rest of the day, Iaposd have been guttedI didnapost lose any weight. But guess what  I did. I lost a whopping lbs. Which just goes to show sticking to aposfree foodsapos and the rest of the rules of the Slimming World plan does do the trick.Do you have a story to share  Weaposd love to hear all about it. story: I dont want my dad walking my cousin down the aisle after she bullied meAn anonymous woman took to Reddit to share her story, explaining that her dad had been asked to walk his cousin down the aisle but she wanted him to refuse as the woman used to bully herA woman left her family ided after saying she didnt want her dad walking her cousin down the aisle Image: Getty Images Image SourceByJohn BettAudience Writer:,  Feb |comments A woman has left her family ided after saying she didnapost want her dad to walk her cousin down the aisle - as she used to bully her.Sharing her story anonymously, the -year-old woman said that her uncle had passed away so her dad became a stand-in parent for the cousin, . But the cousin didnapost make le easy for the woman, and would bully her in an attempt to aposstealapos her dad. Now, the cousin is getting married and the younger woman didnapost want him walking her down the aisle - and now the whole family have been left ided. What do you think the dad should do  Let us know in the comments...Taking to Reddit, the woman said: While the bullying decreased it never went away, she still makes fun of me because Iaposm single, because Iaposm dumb, etc etc. When she got engaged she excluded me from the bridal party and it wouldnapost matterit wasnapost for the fact that she included the rest of the family. She took my parents to dinner last week and asked my dad to walk her down the aisle and I donapost know what excuse he gave her but after that, he came to my room and asked meI would be okay with this.  I was honest, I said no. I told him that she made most of my le hell, even before my uncle passed away and since I was his only daughter, I thought it would be an experience between us. Well, my dad told her no and now my cousin is blaming me, telling everyone that I forced him, that I was a jealous little b***h and thatI donapost fix it then I wouldnapost be welcome at her wedding.  My mum and my aunt sided with her that it was a low blow on my part and most of her family is saying that it wasnapost fair. After sharing her story online, other Reddit users rushed to the womanaposs defence and said that they too would be uncomfortable,they found themselves in a similar situation. One said: Your cousin is an a*****e, and all those comments are extremely mean - especially considering youaposre a teenager and sheaposs an adult  It seems like you are already aware that sheaposs the only one in the wrong, though. Then another wrote: He asked, you answered. The people in your family are cowards and nasty for coming at a teen like that over a grown manaposs decision And a third added: Your father is an adult and can make his own decisions. Itaposs good that heaposs taking your feelings into consideration, but he honestly isnapost going far enough. He should have stood up for you before and definitely needs to set the record straight with your family.Do you have a story to share  Weaposd love to hear all about it. story: Women are just discovering why their shirts button on the left and not rightWomens blouses tend to button on the left, while mens shirts are more likely to have fastenings along the right-hand side – and theres an interesting reason whyWomens shirts button on the left, but why  Image: Getty Images iStockphotoByJohn BettAudience WriterBillie Schwab DunnFeatures Writer:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb |comments It has been an interesting year of discovery for women - more specically, womenaposs clothes - as two stories emerged explaining why they are dferent to menaposs clothing.Now internet sleuths have turned their attention to shirts, and why the buttons on womenaposs are on the opposite side to menaposs.As the Daily Star reports, there are a iety of theories as to why this may be the case, and one dates back to when men were locked in battle, and another theory is to do with child-rearing.Melanie M. Moore, founder of womenaposs blouse brand Elizabeth  Clarke, has a dferent theory and thinks she may have unearthed the reason once and for all. Why do you think womenaposs blouses button on the opposite side to menaposs shirts  Let us know in the comments...One thoery is that menaposs shirts had buttons on the right side because most men held their swords in their right hand. This meant they needed to be able to unbutton their shirt quickly to duel and unbuttoning using their left hand was faster. As to why womenaposs buttons are on the left, many believe itaposs because women tend to carry their babies in their left arms.  Itaposs possible that womenaposs shirts were designed to be opened or closed with the free right hand to make breastfeeding easier, so they were buttoned on the left and open on the right. It also may be because way back when women were expected to ride horses sidesaddle. Buttoning up on the left may have kept the breeze from blowing up their shirts as they galloped across fields.  Another possible explanation for the iation in button placement could be traced back to the rise of emancipation when women began to abandon their girdles in favour of pants and other traditionally male clothes. As a practical technique of distinguishing between menaposs and womenaposs clothing, manufacturers placed buttons on the left side of womenaposs clothing. Melanie M. Moore, founder of womenaposs blouse brand Elizabeth  Clarke, has a dferent theory. When buttons were invented in the th century they were, like most new technology, very expensive, she told Today. Wealthy women back then did not dress themselves — their ladyaposs maid did. Since most people were right-handed, this made it easier for someone standing across from you to button your dress. There are a iety of possible reasons as to why menaposs and womenaposs shirts are buttoned dferently. At this point though, it all comes down to good old-fashioned tradition.Do you have a story to share  Weaposd love to hear all about it. According to Italian American food writer Marcella Hazan, a good pasta sauce is remarkably simple and economical, too, meaning itaposs far cheaper and healthy than any store bought products.  Marcella, who died in , was born in Cesenatico, Italy, in  and went on to open a New York cookery school and write hugely respected cookbooks, so what she says goes when it comes to a good old pasta sauce. In one of her books, Essentials of Classic Italian Cooking, Marcella advises using only three ingredients in tomato sauce: tinned tomatoes, an onion and a generous knob butter. We told you it was simple. The  recipe is still revered by food writers and cooks alike. No chopping is required. And pasta and tomato sauce is always a hit round the family dining table. Marcellaaposs precise instructions are to put half a peeled onion into a pot with butter and tinned tomatoes and to leave it all to simmer for  minutes. story: Boy, , stuck at bottom of ft well for  days as rescuers desperately dig to save himThe boy, who was identied only by his first name, Rayan, fell into the well in the northern hill town of Chefchaouen, Morocco, on Tuesday - sparking a massive rescue operationRayan, a -year-old Moroccan boy who has been stuck in a deep well for almost three days Image: TwitterByAhmed EljechtimiGraeme Murray:,  Feb |commentsA five-year-old boy has been stuck at the bottom of a ft well for three days as rescuers are desperately digging to get to him. The little lad, who was identied only by his first name, Rayan, fell into the well in the northern hill town of Chefchaouen, Morocco, on Tuesday. His distraught mum said in a video shown on local media: I ask Moroccans to pray for the safeof my son. Rayanaposs father told news site Le he had been repairing the well when the boy fell into it. The rescue mission is complex because the well is  metres deep and gets more narrow as it descends. It starts from -inches in diameter at the top, meaning the rescuers cannot go down themselves to retrieve the child.  The hilly region around Chefchaouen is bitterly cold in winter and though food has been lowered to Rayan, it was not clear whether he has eaten any. Rescuers have also given Rayan water and oxygen through a tube as they continue their complex mission. They are working through the night with bulldozers to cut a massive trench into the hill next to the well.  Once they reach the same depth as the well the rescuers can start digging horizontally to save him, a witness told Reuters. By am GMT on Friday, authorities said there were less than ft of earth left to dig to reach him. Pictures from the scene showed multiple diggers delving deep into the earth from multiple directions. as small crowds gathered on the edge of the ever-growing pit.  State news outlet SNRT News quoted a rescuer on Friday saying the boy was still alive even after being stuck in the well since Tuesday. One of the rescue team told local media on Friday: We are preparing the most critical and most complicated rescue step ...we need to dig horizontally three to five meters.apos But to do so we have to stabilise the earth and remove the risk of a landslide because we will deploy a rescue team and we cannot jeopardise their lives.  Authorities have prepared a helicopter to take the boy to the hospital once he is freed, national news channel M said. Lead rescuer Abdelhabi Temrani told Al Oula television that the diameter of the well was less than  centimetres. News of the rescue mission sparked an outpouring of sympathy online, with the Arabic hashtag #SaveRayan going viral across the North African region, including in neighbouring Algeria. aposThe heart of every Moroccan is with this angel,apos one person wrote on Twitter.The boyaposs fate has also attracted crowds of people to the site of the operation, putting pressure on rescuers operating in dficult conditions, it was said. baby when a woman went into labour during a long-haul flight. Dr Stephen Ansah-Addo, a dermatology resident, was on a flight from Ghana to Dallas, Texas, when the emergency call went out on the tannoy. A pregnant woman, whose name has only been given as GG, had gone into labour prematurely aboard United Flight UA last month. Air stewards then asked passengersa health professional was on-board, and Dr Ansah-Addo and a nurse both sprang into action. The pair turned the area behind business class into a makesht operation room - putting down blankets and towels. Dr Ansah-Addo felt the babyaposs head an hour after the mumaposs contractions became more frequent.  Video footage shows the new mum with her baby boy - after giving birth to him mid-flight. Paramedics were ready to meet the plane when it touched down at Dulles International Airport after an almost -hour journey. Fellow passenger Tiani Warren, , who witnessed the drama unfold from across the aisle, described the birth as a total miracle. She said: I was just having a nap when I started hearing these loud groans from further down the plane. I was really concerned and when I went over to investigate I saw a woman was in labour. It caused a bit of panic, and the pilot was considering making an emergency landing in Bermuda so GG could make it to a hospital. But, as it turned out, there was no time for that, and she had her baby right there and then. Thankfully an off duty dermatologist and a nurse were on board to deliver the baby. I donapost know what would have happenedit hadnapost of been for their professionalism. It was certainly an eventful flight, and Iaposm just so relieved the birth was relatively smooth. The whole thing was just so crazy, but it all turned out okay in the end. I wish GG and her baby boy all the best for the future. title: family horrified after dna test
story: Family horried after DNA test shows adult IVF baby isn’t related to her dadThe Harveys have accused Summa Health System of malpractice, negligence and fraud, alleging the doctor and his health practice failed to “safeguard” John’s genetic materialJeanine and John have only recently discovered their daughter is not related to her dad Image: Harvey FamilyByAlice Peacock:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb |comments A family is suing their doctor after a DNA test showed their adult IVF baby isn’t related to her dad, prompting their claims that a stranger’s sperm was used in the  insemination.According to the lawsuit filed on Wednesday, Jeanine and John “Mike” Harvey said they discovered their daughter Jessica was not biologically related to her father following a DNA test. The family, from Ohio in the US, have accused Summa Health System of malpractice, negligence and fraud. The couple alleged the health practice failed to “properly collect” and “safeguard” John’s genetic material. Speaking in a virtual press conference, Jeanine said she and John had been to see a fertility doctor for help around  years ago. She claimed they “couldn’t have been clearer” in their goal, which was to have a child who was genetically related to both of them.  “I underwent the in vitro fertilisation with the understanding that Mike’s genetic materials would be used in this procedure,” she said. The family first learned of the alleged botched procedure upon purchasing a DNA test for Jessica, before she went to Europe in . Jeanine explained the family thought the it could be “cool” for her to connect with distant relatives in the countries she visited.  However, instead of her father’s Italian heritage on her test, Jessica instead found that she was of Irish, English, German, Welsh and French descent. Jessica said there were “no words” to express what she and her parents had been through and claimed she was in “total disbelief”. The organisation has made a statement to local media outlets saying it was taking the allegations “seriously”. “At this point, we have not met with the family or conducted testing of our own. Given the very limited information that we have and the amount of time that has passed, it remains our hope that the attorneys representing the family will work with us to make that next step a priority,” Mike Bernstein, system director of Corporate Communications for Summa Health System, said. Jessica had since tracked down her biological father through ancestry and genealogists hired by her lawyer. It has been confirmed that the man gave sperm for an insemination procedure on the same day the Harveys were in his office. The Harvey family have said they hope their lawsuit will lead to federal oversight of the fertility industry. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. NowHelensburghMore than  houses will be built on the site of Helensburgh Golf Cluban application submitted to Argyll and Bute Council is approved.Taylor Wimpey officially applied for planning permission at the site on East Abercromby Street in the latter part of , and the application has now been validated by Argyll and Bute Council and published on the authority’s website.As well as  residential units the plans also include demolition of the golf club’s existing clubhouse, the building of a new clubhouse and the provision of an enhanced -hole golf course.Feedback can now be given to the authority, with a decision expected from planning officers by Thursday May .A design and access statement by Taylor Wimpey states: #There is a recognised need for new housing within the settlement of Helensburgh.#During the preparation of the Local Development Plan, the council approached the golf club to discuss the possibility of relocating the golf course to provide additional housing land in a sustainable location.#The golf club saw this as an opportunity to improve the existing golf course offer in the area whilst providing land for much-needed housing.#This ultimately led to an area of the golf course being allocated for housing in the adopted Argyll and Bute Local Development Plan.#Members of Helensburgh Community Council have already raised concerns about the impact of increased traffic on East Abercromby Street leading to and from the development’s single access point.In response Taylor Wimpey have said: #Access to the site is currently obtained from East Abercromby Street and the site is bisected roughly north-south by the Old Luss Road footpath and cycleway.#The proposed development will be accessed from a new priority junction on East Abercromby title: lochgilphead composer creates new islay symphony
story: Updated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwards.Subscribe NowThe Royal Scottish National Orchestra has recorded a new symphony written by a Lochgilphead composer who was inspired by the beauty of Islay.The Rinns of Islay, composed by Helen MacKinnon, is a -minute symphony that portrays #a musical journey around the Inner Hebridean island#, which was home to the composer’s grandparents and generations before.Inspired by stories of Islay in her youth, Helen began sketching the work during her composition studies at The University of Glasgow and ed to complete the work nearly  years later.The -minute piece for symphony orchestra was recorded in Glasgow Royal Concert Hall, with American-based PARMA Recordings and GRAMMY-winning producer Brad Michel.Helen, who grew up in Lochgilphead. explained: #It was a privilege to record with Scotland’s national orchestra.#The musicians and conductor, David Watkin, breathed glorious le into the work, which takes us on a musical journey around the island.#Due to Covid, we had a cross-Atlantic recording team, with technology connecting a producer in Boston with a team on the ground in Glasgow. It was a fascinating experience.#The new orchestral work was inspired by Islay’s stunning natural environment, known for its rich terrain and peaty whisky.Five short thematic movements celebrate Islay’s sunrises and coastal shores, while giving a playful nod to the island’s abundant whisky industry.Helen added: #The work centres around The Rinns – a beautul peninsula overlooking the Atlantic Ocean.#My father used to talk about The Rinns of Islay, and as a child, I started to create stories and soundscapes linked to the island.#The work offers a visual, almost cinematic listening experience, with atmospheres and landmarks inspiring the visual imagination.#The work features on a new album Legends and Light Vol. , featuring works by seven composers.While many of the pieces are arranged for orchestral ensembles, listeners will also find the Highland bagpipes and Irish Uilleann pipes featured on the album, offering a deeply rewarding listening experience.Helen is delighted with feedback so far: #I’m thrilled with audiences’ responses to the music.#Listeners have tuned in from across the UK, the USA and as far afield as New Zealand, keeping Scotland on the international map for new music.#

title: debut-goal-new-gala-fairydean-rovers-signing
story: MARTIN Scott believes that Gala Fairydean Rovers’ attacking philosophy will suit new signing Scott Cusick’s style and he will be a good addition to the squad.The Glaswegian came off the bench to score the winner against Dalbeattie Star on Saturday but had to be replaced late on after ‘working his socks off.’Scott said: “We just brought Scotty in recently who was available as a free agent. I had actually played with Scotty when he was on loan at Brechin City from Dunfermline, so I knew what he was capable of. I knew he would fit into our philosophy and how we want to play the game.“My intention was to give him - minutes, but he came on early and worked his socks off and got his reward with the goal and then we had to being him back off because his legs had just went at that point.“He probably needs a bit more game time in terms of match fitness and sharpness but when he gets up to full speed, he will be a real asset for us.“We went short-term and this gives him a chance to get back playing and enjoying his football. And it gives us the opportunity to let him see what we are about and come the end of the season we will probably assess that again.“Everyone knows Gala is a great club. I think that little bit of professionalism and trying to do things in the right manner will help bring him on. He came down and trained with us and as soon as he met the chairman and the boys make everyone feel welcome when they come to the club .“There is a real togetherness there so I think it will suit Scotty going forward so it’s up to him what he does from here until the end of the season. I told him that he will get an opportunity to play but he needs to show me that he’s here to contribute.“He has a good pedigree at Dunfermline and Celtic as a kid and he’s got a good attitude but has just lost his way a bit in terms of going on loan to Brechin City when they were in League Two. It was a tough ask to come in and play men’s football when they were just desperate for results. So it probably wasn’t the ideal fit for him. Going forward, coming to us will suit him as he has an eye for a pass and an eye for a goal and is comfortable on both feet. He can go outside or inside and has a bit of pace. He’ll be a really good addition. “

title: natural-beauty-history-borders-inspires-photographers
story: A COLOURFUL image of sheep grazing on the purple heather of The Gypsy Glen in the Tweed Valley has been ranked by VisitScotland as the most popular Scottish Borders social media post of .The photograph by @becky__ received more than , likes when it was shared by the national tourism organisation on its Instagram account, making it the highest performing post of the region last year.An image of Sir Walter Scott’s ancestral home at Abbotsford House near Melrose was ranked second most popular post for the region. The image, which was captured by @flordeescocia and received more than , likes, shows the stunning Baronial property through an open gate from the surrounding landscaped gardens.The third highest performing post was by photographer Martin Donald Smithwho captured an atmospheric image of the dark skies above Smailholm Tower that attracted more than , likes.Between January  and January , VisitScotland’s Instagram reached people over  million times with  user-generated posts. The channel has played an important role in keeping Scotland front of mind and inspiring potential visitors during the global pandemic.VisitScotland launched its global marketing campaign Scotland is Calling last year, aimed specically at overseas visitors who, research suggests, spend longer planning and researching their trips.VisitScotland Regional Leadership Director Paula Ward said: “The wide-open spaces, natural beauty and history of the Scottish Borders are a fantastic source of inspiration for photographers and these images have captured some of the many reasons visitors are drawn to the region.“VisitScotland’s social media channels have played an important role in the last two years in continuing to keep Scotland front of mind and offering inspiration to our global audiences for when they can travel. We know there is pent-up demand for travel and we want to ensure that we inspire potential visitors with what Scotland has to offer and make it their first-choice destination when they can travel..remove“Tourism is a force for good – creating economic and social value in every corner of Scotland and enhancing the wellbeing of everyone who experiences it. Tourism makes Scotland richer, economically and socially, and without it Scotland would be a much poorer place.”Abbotsford Trust Chief Executive Giles Ingram said: “We are thrilled that this stunning shot of Abbotsford was such a popular image in . It gives you a sneak-peak into the glorious walled gardens, with Scott’s “conundrum castle” beyond.“Social media has been invaluable to our charity over the past couple of years, allowing us to bring the experience of Abbotsford to people in their own home. We have been delighted to see visitor numbers begin to recover in  and look forward to welcoming more visitors to Abbotsford as we celebrate the th anniversary of Sir Walter Scott throughout .”

title: eco-group-launches-new-borders-food-project
story: A NEW environmentally friendly food project has been set up in the Borders with the aim of encouraging people to grow their own food.Gardens for the Future is a project created by Greener Melrose, a group working towards a sustainable future in the Borders.The project was launched at the group’s flagship site at Drygrange, near Leaderfoot.Chair of Greener Melrose Donald McPhillimy said: “We start by putting our new leaflet through the letter boxes of a whole neighbourhood. This invites householders to consider growing more fresh nutritious food in their own gardens.“If they are interested, they contact us at greenermelrose@live“We then form a group and get them started.”The project aims to create a number of ‘growing circles’ – spaces where people can share their gardening skills, receive training and support, and access free materials and tools to help them on their gardening journey.Donald added: “We realise that people have a few obstacles to getting started but we want to knock them aside by sharing skills, providing training and mutual support, providing free compost, soil and seeds to get started, timber for raised beds, lending tools and so on.“This is the ideal time of year to be setting up vegetable gardens, so we hope lots of people will come forwards.”Greener Melrose has printed , leaflets to be posted in communities which should allow for  growing circles to be formed around the region.The local project has been initially funded by Action Earth and Nature Scot.Greener Melrose is also part of the Scottish Borders Local Food Growing Network – a network convened by Scottish Borders Council and sees groups across the Borders come together to exchange ideas and develop new projects.

title: council-seeks-views-lockdown-traffic-measures
story: BORDERERS are asked to give their feedback on the trial traffic measures introduced since the start of the pandemic.In  Scottish Borders Councilintroduced the trial  mph limits in between Lauder and Earlston, and between Heriot Stow Fountainhall and Clovenfords and restricted road access on the Caddonfoot Road .Now the local authority wants locals views on the programme of measures andthey should be made permanent.“The COVID- pandemic and the resulting lockdowns provided the Council with the perfect opportunity to trial ious measures that had the potential to make our roads safer whilst also encouraging more exercise and active travel," said councillor Gordon Edgar, executive member for infrastructure, travel and transport at SBC.For the areas where temporary  mph limits were introduced, SBC wants to determinepermanent signage should be installed orthe stretches of road shouldto the national speed limit.Restricted access was added to the Caddonfoot Road on July , , to increase pedestrian access to the playing field and to be safer for exercise.Due to the insufficient space on the verge for a pavement, SBC wants to hear about peoples experiences and seethere is a demand for allowing vehicles on the road again orit should be kept closed.Mr Edgar said: “Now is the right time to reassess these measures and we are extremely keen for as many people as possible to share their views to help determine the future of these backroads.”Surveys for both the  mph speed limits and Caddonfoot Road are now live and will be open until February .The  mph speed limit trial survey can be found at:www.scotborders.gov.uk mphconsultationAnd the survey for Caddonfoot Road can be accessed at:www.scotborders.gov.uk caddonfootroadconsultation

story: This will be a proud weekend for the Borders town of Hawick with Stuart Hogg captaining Scotland against the Auld Enemy England tomorrow in the Calcutta Cup match at BT Murrayfield and Rhys Tait doing likewise for the Us tonight at the DAM Health Stadium.Boroughmuir Bear Tait leads Scotland out for the first time from openside flanker as the age-grade sideto play in Scotland for the first time since February .Born and raised in Hawick, Tait started his rugby career at Jed-Forest Minis aged  years old and has already represented Scotland at U and U age-grade level.Tait will be joined in the back row by Matt Deehanwho will make his first appearance in the squad at blindside flanker and Exeter University’s Ollie Leatherbarrow at No  who featured in all five of Scotland’s games last year.Edinburgh Rugby’s Patrick Harrison who enjoyed a successful spell with the Southern Knights last year will start at hooker and will pack down alongside Tom Bantavalaand Currie Chieftains Gregor Scougall who s from injury to take his place in the squad and is set to make his first Scotland U appearance.The imposing figure of Max Williamsonwillto the squad in the second-row and will be joined by Josh Taylor from Ealing Trailfinders.Behind the scrum Jed Gelderbloomstarts at scrum-half and will partner Ayrshire Bulls, and Glasgow Warriors, Christian Townsend at stand-off.It’s an all Boroughmuir Bears mid-field as Mike Gray starts at inside-centre and Duncan Munn at outside him. Ross McKnightand Ollie Melvilleline up on the wings, with Montpellier’s Robin McClintock starting at full-back.Coach Kenny Murray said: “The team are in a really good place after working hard over the last few months.“I’m really happy with the squad we’ve been able to select,  players have played in an international match of this level before, so they know what to expect..remove“It will be a really special night at the DAM Health Stadium on Friday as this group of players get to experience representing their country for the first time on home soil since all  Under- Six Nations fixtures were held in Cardf.“A large crowd is expected so it should be a great atmosphere to open our campaign with.”Scotland U’s opening round of the Under- Six Nations at DAM Health Stadium kicks off at pm and can be watched live on BBC iPlayer.

title: prime-minister-not-law-says-borders-mp
story: TWO Conservative Borders politicians are united in their belief that Sue Gray’s report should be published in full and that the British public have a right to see the evidence for themselves.When allegations first emerged of parties in Downing Street, Prime Minister Boris Johnson told parliament he had obeyed all lockdown rules.Subsequent evidence showed he had personally attended what appeared to be social events.Civil Servant Sue Gray was tasked with investigating the circumstances and was expected to produce a comprehensive report.However last week the politan Police launched a parallel investigation which resulted in a heavily edited version of her report being published. This sparked a furious debate in the House of Commons.No guarantee was given by the Prime Minister that an unredacted report would be made available to MPs.In response Borders MP John Lamont said: “It is deeply frustrating that Sue Gray has been unable to release her full report so that we can see the full facts of what has gone on. The country has a right to see the evidence for themselves and it must be published in full when the police investigation concludes.”MP for Dumfriesshire, Clydesdale and Tweeddale David Mundell said: “The document which has been presented by Sue Gray is an update on her investigation into alleged gatherings on Government premises during Covid restrictions. It details a number of alleged gatherings, all but four of which are now subject to a separate investigation by the politan Police and, as a result, details of those events have not been reported in the update in order not to prejudice the police investigations.“My strong view is that, when it is possible, the report in its entirety should be published, as I believe everyone has a right to see what has been established.”Both also insisted that anyone found to have broken the lawshould be held accountable.Mr Lamont added: “No one is above the law. Not even the Prime Minister. Those found to have broken the law must be held accountable.”.removeMr Mundell said: “Equally, should the ongoing police investigation conclude that there is evidence warranting proceedings against any of the iniduals involved, then those proceedings must be taken forward as they would against any other member of the public.”

title: coronavirus-borders-pcr-test-site-close-next-month
story: THE only site for coronavirus PCR tests in the Borders will close next month, a meeting has heard.Senior councillor Gordon Edgar said the local authority has served a notice, on behalf of Live Borders, on the UK Health Security Agency to vacate the community centre in Langlee.The news comes after concerns were raised that residents were being ‘deprived’ of a vital hub.NHS Borders says it is “exploring other options for PCR testing provision” in the region.:Borders Railway extension project dead in the water, says transport chiefMr Edgar – the executive member for infrastructure, travel and transport – told the meeting: “Scottish Borders Council served notice on behalf of Live Borders on the UK Health Security Agency to vacate by March , . They have advised that the site will cease testing on March ,  and will be demobilised.”Mr Edgar said last year that the current lease was set to expire in January, but the UK Government asked that the PCR test sites remain operational until March.Galashiels councillor Harry Scott said that “many groups” have been forced to evacuate the centre due to its use as a PCR testing site.“This centre is located in one of the areas where it houses some of the poorest and most disadvantaged in our community and the loss of the facility has had a great effect,” he said.:Borders politicians want Sue Grays report to be published in fullFollowing concerns raised by Mr Scott over reported damage to the floor at the centre, Mr Edgar confirmed that any necessary reinstatement work would be carried out.An NHS Borders spokesperson said: “Currently PCR tests are available via the walk-through site at Langlee Community Centre, a Mobile Testing Unitwhich circulates between strategic sites in the Borders and home delivery by ordering online or calling .“We are exploring other options for PCR testing provision in the Borders, in line with national directives, and discussions with local partner organisations are ongoing.”.removeThe centre’s testing facility and MTU are both provided by the UK Government’s Department of Health and Social Care.

title: hawick-woman-obtained-8k-benefits-not-entitled
story: A BORDERS woman who obtained more than £, in benefits she was not entitled to has been ordered to carry out  hours of unpaid work at Jedburgh Sherf Court.Thirty-eight-year-old Carrie Whillans, of Harwood Cottage, Hawick, received £, in income support and also £, in housing benefit between September  and December  she was not entitled to as she was residing with her partner at the time.Defence lawyer Ross Dow said his client had an on-off relationship with her partner at the time.He added she was in process of repaying the money.Whillans was given nine months to complete the unpaid work.

title: music-peebles-marks-75th-year-popular-quartet
story: is a big milestone in the history of Music in Peebles.The group is marking its th season since its formationin .It is also a big year for their very special guests in February, the Brodsky Quartet.An appearance by the group is always an eagerly-awaited highlight, but this appearance is all the more special for being part of the quartets th anniversary celebrations.Coincidentally, the Brodsky Quartet last came to Peebles in , while marking their th anniversary.The programme for the night starts with Borodin Scherzo in D for String Quartet, followed by Schubert String Quartet No. in A minor, D. , James MacMillan “For Sonny” and “Memento” and Shostakovich String Quartet No. in E flat, Op..The concert culminates in the enigmatic th Quartet by Shostakovich, a composer with whose music the Brodsky Quartet is particularly associated.Paul Cassidy, the groups violist, describes the th as “one of the most exhilarating of the whole cycle” ending with “one of the greatest finales of the string quartet literature. title: youngsters-help-keep-roads-safe-around-school
story: KELSOs Junior Road Safety Officers were out in force this week helping police to carry out speed checks outside Broomlands Primary School.On Wednesday the youngsters joined officers from the Scottish Borders Police Community Action Team to deter speeders and help keep the roads safe.One of the Scottish Borders Local Policing Priorities is to Improving Road Safety and the Community Action Team are funded by the Scottish Borders Council to deal with local issues such as this.The JRSOs and their teams are a huge help to the Road Safety Officer for the local area, as they help promote road safety issues within the school and local community.More than % of primary schools in Scotland now have JRSOs and their ethos is one of pupil empowerment and partnership working to enable children to become successful learners, confident iniduals, responsible citizens and effective contributors.They talk at assemblies and to classes on road safety topics, run competitions in the school, get prizes for the winners and hand out merit certicates, write letters and get involved in organising safe and active travel activities.JSRO’s are normally Primary  pupils, or pupils at the end of Primary , who apply for the job by filling in an application form stating they have to say why they would like the job and what would make them a good JRSO.The applicants may then be asked to attend an interview.
