title: ushering in a new dawn for
story: An Tìr, An Cànan, ‘S na DaoineFor the pioneering four-piece group from Skye, Gaelic is central to what they do – but don’t call them standard bearers for the language. They prefer instead to view Gaelic as a natural medium for their music # a not atypical outlook for their island generation raised with the language as part of their education during the s.And this should be encouraging, for the key to the future survival of the language will lie not in its exceptionalism, but in its ordinariness.While Gaelic may be natural to Niteworks, what sets them apart is how they use it. Their trademark sound is forged from the rich Hebridean song tradition of their native communities, and the dance music they listened to in their bedrooms, and later in Glasgow nightclubs.They have just released their third album # A’ Ghrian,– which follows the eponymous debut album of  and Air Fàir An Làwhich came out in .In what should have been one of the marquee events of Glasgow’s Celtic Connections festival, last Friday Niteworks should have been on stage with the Royal Scottish National Orchestra. But to immense frustration and disappointment, Covid restrictions were not been lted in time and the concert has been rescheduled for the summer.Unsurprisingly, lockdown and the pandemic are themes that have influenced the new album, says band member Allan MacDonald.. “It has been over two years since I have been to a club as a punter.“That was a huge part of our lives. I wouldn’t say it has changed our musical tastes, but what we listen to at home now is dferent to what we would listen to in a club.“That has influenced us and the direction we are going as a band. We’re also getting a bit older, there’s two in the band that have young families now and this album is perhaps a bit more reflective than the others.”It is approaching  years since the quartet put on their first gig – at Braes Hall as part of the year of Highland culture celebrations in . Their first EP followed in , and Niteworks have since become regulars on the festival circuit # including annual appearances at SkyeLive in Portree.They aren’t full time as a band, however, and online rehearsing was a familiar process to them long before the outset of the pandemic.Allan, who is from Braes and from a family of pipers, works in renewable energy and is based in London. Synth and keyboard player Innes Strachan from Breakish works in sound production in Glasgow drummer Ruaraidh Graham, also from Breakish, works in Edinburgh for Historic Environment Scotland and bass player Chris Nicolson, from Braes, is with the BBC in Inverness.One of their ‘lockdown projects’ included writing the music to mark Edinburgh’s Hogmanay, and in turn this led to the orchestral collaboration and the more ‘expansive and cinematic’ sound of the new album, says Ruairidh Graham.“We were partly inspired by our work writing the music for Edinburgh’s Hogmanay Fare Well film that reflected on what  had been like for many during the pandemic,” he adds. “The nature of the project required broad expansive sounds, and that led to us going further in that direction through the writing and recording of the album.“Our upcoming orchestral concert for Celtic Connections further reinforced our desire to keep down that path.”There is an abundance of vocal talent to be found on A’ Ghrian, including from long-time collaborators Sian . Celebrated Scottish singers Kathleen MacInnes, Beth Malcolm, Hannah Rarity and Alasdair Whyte also feature, and Niteworks have incorporated English folk and Scots songs into their repertoire for the first time.The album, which was funded by Creative Scotland and recorded in autumn , also features Fiona MacAskill, Aileen Reid and Laura Wilkie of Kinnaris Quintet alongside Susan Appelbe on strings.A’ Ghrian is available to buy on CD and stream and download on all digital s, and the band will tour the until the end of . A documentary on the band is also due to be aired on BBC Alba soon.

title: tobar an dualchais brides day the birthday of
story: An Tìr, An Cànan, ‘S na Daoine or ‘the dead month’.   or Saint Bride’s Day. This falls in with ‘Candlemas’ on nd February as a Christian festival and a traditional end of the Christmas season. Candlemas commemorates the presentation of the infant Jesus at the Temple in Jerusalem as described in St Luke’s Gospel and when some denominations bring candles to their church. Candlemas is also one of the so-called ‘Quarter-days’ marking the changing seasons of winter, spring, summer and autumn. It is followed by Whitsun, Lammas Day and Martinmas as the term-days with their administrative and legal implications for the payment of rents and flittings. Saint Bride or Saint Bridget has been one of the most popular of the saints of the celtic church. Of course, there were many ‘Bridgets’, but the one whose festival date is on st February was ‘Bridget of Kildare’ in Leinster whose death was dated to AD . Bridget was one of the patron saints of Ireland and is remembered in the tradition of plaiting rush crosses around st February to set over doors and windows to protect the home from fire and other danger.   or the endearing ‘Bride’s little fosterling’.’ . ‘Bride’s Day, the birthday of spring’. century, traditions of Saint Bride were collected by Alexander Carmichael among his prayers, hymns, blessings and charms from the Hebrides. He suggests that accounts of Saint Bride were not easily recovered and summarised the tradition: ‘The serpent is supposed to emerge from its hollow among the hills on St Bride’s Day, and a propitiatory hymn was sung to it. Only one verse of this hymn has been obtained, apparently the first. It dfers in dferent localities: [Early on Bride’s mornThe serpent shall come from the hole, I shall not molest the serpent, Nor will the serpent molest me.’ The snake is a powerful element in mythology and religion and a creature to be respected as the ‘hymn’ makes clear. Familiar in the snake coiled round the rod, it is a symbol of medicine and healing, and the appearance of the adder or snake on Saint Bride’s Day offers a feeling of hope and transformation, and of turning the corner with the ening of the days. . century. .!... !

title: special donnie munro concert to bring skye live back with a
story: An Tìr, An Cànan, ‘S na DaoineThe island#s premier music festival is set toin style on Thursday th May # following a two-year break due to the pandemic # with an opening night extravaganza # ‘Coming Home: An Evening with Donnie Munro and friends’ and featuring special guests in the form of multi-award-winning Gaelic supergroup Mànran.The show will be Donnie’s first in his hometown since  and will see him perform with a full eight-piece band line-up on the spectacular Skye Live Festival site at Am Meall in Portree. The singer said: #This offers me a fantastic opportunity to bring this amazing line-up, featuring some of Scotland’s top musicians together, for an exclusive performance to open this year’s Skye Live Festival.He added: #It has been fantastic to watch the festival grow in strength, year on year, in what must be one of the most special and unique festival locations anywhere in the world, and to see it become internationally recognised as, ‘one of the best boutique festivals in the country’, is just fantastic for the island, and it is such a great honour for me to be invited to be a part of it all and to be bringing the music back home here to where it all began.#Joining Donnie Munro on the night will be Mànran, internationally recognised as one of the most iconic and respected Scottish bands on the road today. With three hugely successful studio albums under their belt, in October  the band released their fourth, titled ÙRAR to critical acclaim, and adding to their success, lead female vocalist, Kim Carnie was crowned ‘Gaelic Singer of the Year’ at the  Hands up for Trad Awards.Mànran founder and accordionist Gary Innes said: #Playing on the Isle of Skye has always been a special night for Mànran over the years but joining Donnie and his band as their special guests for Skye Live will certainly be a night to remember.#.

title: local entrepreneurs are urged to go for it in 2022
story: Almost , entrepreneurs across Northern Ireland have been supported by the Go For It Programme over the past four years, with more than , new business plans drawn up in .The scheme, which aims to help entrepreneurs across the country to translate their business idea into reality, is part funded by Invest Northern Ireland and the European Regional Development Fund under the Investment for Growth  Jobs Northern IrelandProgramme.Mid and East Antrim BC has banded together with Council areas across Northern Ireland to urge local entrepreneurs to Go For It’ in  with the support of the programme. During , Mid and East Antrim BC delivered  inidual business plans to budding business owners.The Go For It programme is delivered free of charge by a team of experienced business advisors across Northern Ireland. It provides expert advice and help with developing a robust business plan, covering everything from financial forecasting to marketing and long-term sales growth. Thanks to the help and support of the Go For It Programme, Darren Black from Larne turned his childhood passion for cars into a successful auto detailing business – Blacky’s Detailing Garage.Darren said: “Whenever I was trying to take it from a part-time venture to a full-time business, I really wasnt sure how to go about it or how to develop a business plan. I got in touch with the Go For It Programme and sat down with my business advisor and they helped me to put together my business plan.“We looked at everything from market research, location of premises to financial forecasting. It really opened my eyes to what was involved and needed to run a professional business. The business plan was fantastic and really helped me to learn and grow as a business owner.”William McCaughey, Mayor of Mid an East Antrim Borough Council, said: “Its absolutely fantastic to see new business ventures like Blackys Detailing Garage seeking the support of the Go For It programme and launching in our Borough.“Entrepreneurs like Darren are going to drive the economic growth of the Borough for years to come.“The Go For It Programme, delivered by Mid and East Antrim Borough Council, provides new entrepreneurs with accessible, free and tailored support in the start-up stage of their business and I would encourage anyone thinking about starting their own business to get in touch!Dr Eugene McGuckin, Programme Manager, Northern Ireland Business Start Up Programme said: “The Go For It Programme continues to be a fantastic asset in helping entrepreneurs across Northern Ireland access the advice and support they need to develop a business plan.“Over , new business plans in three years is a remarkable milestone, and local Councils are really proud that so many entrepreneurs have seized the opportunity to establish the business of their dreams with the support of the Go For It Programme.If you have a business idea you’d like to develop oryou are thinking about starting a business call:    or visit: visit www.goforitni

title: moorfields ps bids farewell to muriel cupples after 44 years dedicated service
story: Moorfields Primary School has said a fond farewell to one of its longest serving members of staff, Mrs Muriel Cupples.Mrs Cupples retired this week after  years of dedicated service as the crossing patrol lady and senior supervisor.After four decades serving the school, Muriel says it is now time to retire at the grand age of .Speaking to the , she said: “I always said I would retire at  and it was my birthday last Sunday so I kept to my word!”There is no doubt she has enjoyed her role, and is a well known figure in the school and the local community, having seen in some cases, two generations of the same families make their way through the classroomsl.“I love the company of the children and my work colleagues and that something I’ll probably miss the most when I retire.“There have been many faces come and go over the years and now I’m crossing children whose parents I crossed years ago!”Muriel revealed she first started working at the school when her children were pupils.“When my children were here the crossing lady at that time was leaving so I thought I would give it a go and here we are  years later!”Many things have undoubtedly changed over Muriel’s tenure, not least the new building Moorfields now enjoys.She added: “I first started when we were in the old school building obviously, so moving to this new one was a big change for everyone!“Obviously staff have changed and I’ve even been here through three principles - Mr Stirling, Mrs Scott and Mrs Dawson. They all have had their own personalities and have brought dferent qualities to the job and I’ve enjoyed working alongside each one.”Another positive change Muriel witnessed was the reduction of the speed limit outside the school to mph.“This really helps,” explains Muriel. “It’s such a busy road, especially with all the lorries coming from Larne so mph at arriving and leaving times is vital.“I’ve had a few near misses with speeding vehicles over the years soeveryone sticks to the mph limit it makes it alot safer for the children.”Although looking forward to her retirement, there are aspects of the job Muriel says she will greatly miss.“I’ll miss everyone I work with and of course the children! “I’ll also miss waving at everyone in the mornings and afternoons because I’ve built up alot of friendships over the years and got to know alot of the parents. I made a great friend through the school, Stella Rea who has sadly passed away, but she was something  and a great lady!“I’ll also miss the children and hearing all their stories and woes! I’ve seen many a fall and tumble and witnessed many games in the playground over the years and can truthfully say I’ve enjoyed every minute.”Chairman of the school’s Board of Governors, Mr Jim Allister paid tribute to Muriel’s years of service. He said: “Often schools are valued and judged on the quality of their teaching etc, but equally often the role played by the support staff is taken for granted.“In Muriel we had for decades that invaluable asset of a dedicated partner in delivering the pastoral care and support to our pupils for which Moorfields is renowned.“Not only has she kept generations of children safe in crossing the very busy main road, but she has been that reliable, compassionate point of contact for so many. Through all weathers, Muriel was there to do her remarkable job with the understatement that betokens her caring commitment.“The school is immensely grateful for her decades of service and wish her well in her retirement.”As Mrs Cupples embarks on this next phase of her le away from Moorfields Primary School she was keen to thank all the staff, pupils and parents for their support over the years.“I just want to say thank you to every single one of you who have made my time here so pleasant. Also a massive thanks for all the gts, the cake, the cards and well wishes you all have given me. I’ve made many friendships over the years and I hope they all continue now as I retire.”

title: wrightbus in major recruitment drive for apprentices
story: LEADING bus manufacturer Wrightbus has announced the recruitment of up to  new apprentices as it gears up for National Apprenticeship Week .The ground-breaking company plans to recruit apprentices in ious roles - including electrical, spray painting, welding, coachbuilding, driveline and engineering. .Wrightbus is supporting its apprenticeship recruitment drive with an open evening on Wednesday February , from -pm, at its Ballymena factory, where people will be able to find out what it is like being a Wrightbus apprentice. Wrightbus sales and business development director, John McLeister, is a huge advocate of apprenticeships. He joined the firm  years ago as an apprentice before working his way up through the ranks.“We’re proud to say our apprentices are playing a key part in driving the business forward,” said Mr McLeister. “We eventually want to have up to  per cent of our workforce on an apprenticeship, via our ious Engineering  Technology Higher Apprenticeship programmes and our general Apprenticeship NI scheme, and this latest recruitment drive will help with that ambition.“They bring ersity, bags of enthusiasm and a fresh approach to problem-solving.”Wrightbus apprentices receive on the job training, working alongside a highly skilled workforce who often act as coaches mentors, along with a college day release programme to back up what they’re learning.Former apprentice Karsten Hall, who started as a design apprentice and now works as a manufacturing engineer, chose a Wrightbus apprenticeship because he wanted to make a start in the world of work.“I wanted a job that provided training and opportunities for progression. I was interested in engineering, so I decided to apply for a Wrightbus apprenticeship,” said Karsten.“From my time on the shopfloor, I gained a lot of hands-on experience with most parts of the build process and a better perspective of how parts are actually assembled and how they can be improved, which helps me in my current role as a manufacturing engineer.”Wrightbus employee Hannah Currie said: “Learning with hands-on experience made a big dference for me, helping with the progression of my career. ‘The experience working with the time-served tradesmen and women, and having such a iety of technology and buses can help you develop so much more knowledge and skills to help you along the way. There are a multitude of opportunities for furthering your career with an apprenticeship.”Sean McAleese, Work Based Learning Managing at Northern Regional College, which works with Wrightbus apprentices, said: “Wrightbus has always been a reliable and trusted employer that has worked closely with the College to develop and implement our apprenticeship programmes at Level , Level  and Higher Level Apprenticeships.“It is great to see the opportunities that have been provided to young people and existing employees who have undertaken an apprenticeship with Wrightbus as well as the high level skills, experience and qualications that they gain. We will continue to partner with the company to identy their training requirements and look forward to strengthening the College’s partnership with Wrightbus in the future.”The National Campaign celebrates the contribution that hundreds of thousands of apprentices make every year to the UK’s economy and encourages more businesses to look to apprenticeships as a solution for recruitment, training, and workforce development. Wrightbus HR Director, Nicola McCloskey, said: “Our apprentices are an invaluable part of our business and we would like to recognise them and thank them for the hard work and effort they put in. They often bring with them new skills and energy, and we’re looking forward to adding to the ranks with this latest round of recruitment.”

Credit: Stephen HamiltonMark BainTwitterEmailFebruary   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailCulnady, in south Derry near Maghera, is not a community any more, it’s just a place where people live.Until two years ago it had a primary school. It was a school all the local children attended.Beside it stood a village shop. It isn’t there any more. The old school building sits empty and crumbling. Where there was the laughter and playing of children, the once beating heart of the community has been stilled.The picture can be copied in many villages and townlands across Northern Ireland where the dwindling number of pupils has led to a red cross being marked against the name of the local school.Just across the border in Co Antrim, Duneane Primary School sits surrounded by farmland, a few miles from Randalstown, a few miles from Toomebridge. It has  pupils across two classes. But that statistic doesn’t tell anyone what the school means to the community.It all starts with a rumour. A subtle hint in an otherwise innocuous message. It could come from the Education Authority, it could come to a dferent school.On January  the Education Authority launched a consultation into the future of area planning in education.Expand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseDistressing: Duneane Primary School board of governors chair Sharon French. Their children are enrolled at a bigger school, further away from the community, a safer option to avoid any distressing move once they have settled in with friends and routine.It’s a threat that many schools in rural areas live with every academic year. Some of them believe they may as well hang a sign on the gate reading ‘Dead School Walking’.That’s far from the case at Duneane, where  pupils arrive every day. All classmates, all friends. All the families part of the same community and they want to stay that way.“We’ve been living with a threat hanging over us for years,” said current chair of the Board of Governors, Sharon French.“So many families who live around here have had generations come to the school. It’s what they know. It’s a family. If it goes, it’s gone. It wouldn’t just be the end of the school, it would be the end of so much more.”Every Christmas the little school is packed with mums and dads, grannies and grandads, aunts and uncles, even those with no connection but who live in the area, to see the children take to the stage, to attend Christmas fairs. It’s a gathering point for charity events, tractors runs.Expand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseLesley Mawhinney, who oversaw the final year at Culnady. Credit. Stephen Hamilton“All those things that keep a community together will disappear too,” said Sharon.“It’ll be like a death in the family.”Fellow governor Kathleen McBride feels there are some schools in Northern Ireland which will always be targeted for closure until the day finally arrives.“There’s a seed planted in communities,” she said, “the fear of a school closing, And once that’s there it’s hard to wash away.“Parents suddenly become very wary of sending their children to smaller schools when something like the recent EA consultation is announced.”That, she said, breeds nothing but suspicion.“It looks like the intention is to bring down numbers at smaller schools to make them less cost effective. If that persists for a long time it has a very detrimental effect.“But we need to look at what a school like Duneane brings to a community, not just statistics on paper. What you save in money you lose in spirit. You just need to be at some of the events held in the school to see the feel-good factor it brings. Closing our small rural schools is killing communities. The school offers a chance for people to be together, but the importance of that seems to be lost on those making the decisions.”Duneane had been earmarked to merge with nearby Moneynick Primary School, but those plans have gone silent.“People can number crunch all they want, but in the end it’s the community that suffers,” she added.“Does anyone actually look at the benefits of strengthening a community rather than undermining it  It’s vitally important to hold on to what we have and little support for what we’re doing wouldn’t go amiss.“A distrust has grown at the handling of school closures and that has been killing morale. We hear all the talk of looking after health and wellbeing, but does anyone really think having to work in a school under a threat of closure is good for anyone’s mental health, including the pupils “This consultation is asking schools for solutions. Supporting rural primary schools can be the solution, but you always worry when a public body has to ask people for ideas.”Culnady Primary School closed its gates in . It had educated local children since the late s.Now principal at Maghera Primary, Lesley Mawhinney was seconded in to oversee the final year and a half in the le of Culnady.“The parents still thought they could still save it, but the decision has been made,” she said.“There was a fabulous parent support group, even though there were just  pupils. The community came to everything the school held, Christmas concerts were packed. The local Young at Heart Group for the elderly people in the community supported everything.The spirit around the school was so much more than in schools where there were hundreds of pupils.“Parents went to Stormont, to the Permanent Secretary, to the EA. They really wanted their children to be educated close to home, but there was nothing they could do.The last few weeks were about protecting the pupils, she said.“There was one family who had moved their children from Drumard Primary when it closed. They had to move again, she added.“The hardest part was clearing out and trying not to let the children see their toys being taken out of cupboards, the equipment from the playground being dismantled, even the clocks being taken off the wall.”Around the same time the school closed, the local shop closed too. The community now has to travel to get essentials.“Before we left an elderly gentleman came to the school and brought an old Culnady book,” said Mrs Mawhinney.“His dad, a past pupil, had died the year before and he’d found an old roll book in the attic. There was a photo of his dad and his brother sitting on the wall outside what was the old school, now the Orange Hall. It was the day before his father went to Cyprus in the Second World War. Those stories are disappearing. The history is gone.”For  years Fiona Brown worked at Desertmartin Primary School, a school with  years of history before it closed in .She has cared for ill parents, watched her brother suffer a stroke at a young age, but said the final three years as a principal overseeing the death throws of a school that was the heart of a community was the most traumatic, distressing experience of her le.And the story of Desertmartin Primary shows that even the much vaunted merger of two schools doesn’t always deliver the happily ever after.Church of Ireland run Desertmartin PS was lined up to join with neighbouring Catholic primary, Knocknagin. It would have been the first jointly-run church school in Northern Ireland. The potential merger stayed on the table despite warnings from parents that it wouldn’t work. The churches failed to reach agreement in time.“We knew Desertmartin was unsustainable,” said Ms Brown, “but it was the  hope and the lack of information no matter how many questions that were asked of all those involved that really killed.“The parents think you now more than you do, but the reality was I knew nothing. That’s hard to deal with.“There’s no handbook on how to close a school. It was left to me to tell parents the news. Then it was left to the school to even sources boxes from local supermarkets to pack up.“A lot of toxicity developed over the course of those final three years, and in the middle of that you’re trying to make sure the children get their education. Staff were left unsure of what to do, whether to apply for other jobs. Had they received a redundancy notice we were told they could go on to a list of available teachers, but as we were Church of Ireland no one seemed to realise that list wasn’t open to them. The whole thing was a complete mess.”Ms Brown said she couldn’t face being a principal again and is now in back in a teaching job.“Every time the phone rang I felt physically sick,” she said.“Three years was a very long time to be living through that. Even having to fight to keep our computers until the school closed was problematic. No-one told us what would happen to the records of the children, their photos we had stored. At the very end no-one could even tell us how to, or who would have to hand over the keys to the building.“There seems to be no understanding of what a rural school means to the community.“There as a certain arrogance from those making the decisions. They looked down on us, patronised us as a wee local school and no one took responsibility or had the guts to tell us exactly what was happening.”Back at Duneane Primary, school le goes on and principal Gail Cuthbertson and her staff treat the pupils as they would their own children. It’s that sort of place.“It’s the same for all smaller rural schools,” she said, “there’s always that fear hanging over you.“Schools are about children. Rural schools are about families and togetherness. Remove the school and people don’t know people anymore. What you’re left with is isolation.”There may be platitudes coming about the great work schools have been doing, words like ‘these are very tough decisions’.But the really tough work is with those who battle on through the uncertainty and are left to nurse a community through closure and themselves through a personally draining and demoralising experience while others congratulate themselves on a FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueProfessor Mike TildesleyLisa SmythTwitterFebruary   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailTake a quick glance at the Department of Health’s Covid- dashboard, and it is obvious that cases of the virus are surging in young people.There have been , positive cases in children aged five to nine over the past seven days. A further , youngsters in the  to -year-old bracket tested positive over the same period.If the figures don’t convince you, speak to any parent. Families that have managed to steer clear of Covid since it arrived almost two years ago are now being struck down by the virus.First, a classmate who is a close contact of a parent with Covid comes to school. Under the rules, they’re allowed to attend as long as they have a negative lateral flow test for  days, but many are going on to develop a Covid infection they then pass on to classmates.It doesn’t help that a child can spend all day sitting next to a friend who later tests positive for Covid — and they are not even considered a close contact.Then, the virus ripples out through year groups. Siblings become infected and, very quickly, large swathes of multiple year groups are unwell and isolating.Professor Ian Young, the chief scientic adviser, said that the highly infectious nature of Omicron meant most schools would be hit by an outbreak,they had not been already.The situation is further exacerbated by the fact that most children are not vaccinated, and there is evidence that previous Delta and Alpha infections do not protect against Omicron.“There is quite a large proportion of under-s with limited immunity,” said Prof Young.“What tends to happenthe virus gets into a classroom or school [is that] it will transmit pretty easily. While [the protections] can reduce the risk, they can’t stop it completely.“There are some schools with quite severe outbreaks and other schools which have had not so much Covid, but sooner or later, most schools are going to have to experience some virus.”So, while we know children are less likely to suffer severe illness from Covid-, it does not mean the impact on their lives is not severe.Even for those children who are asymptomatic, and setting aside the threat posed by long Covid, self-isolation rules are taking their toll on schools.NASUWT national official Justin McCamphill said: “We’re hearing instances where half the school is off with Covid, and then in some schools, it’s half the teachers.“That’s then having a major impact because whole year groups are having to be sent home, and I think that’s being borne out by the absence figures.“That’s causing real anxiety, especially for the exam classes. “I would say this is the worst we have ever seen. It’s becoming impossible for schools to run normal business.”Mental health champion Siobhan O’Neill is also concerned about Covid’s impact in schools.“There have been studies that show really clearly that young people have been displaying signs of stress throughout the pandemic, and young people need their peers to cope with stress,” she said.“They play together to help process that stress. When they don’t get that chance to be together, it does have an impact.“The short answer is there will be an impact on children’s mental health. Most children will be fine, but young people will develop mental ill-health.”Prof O’Neill said this could manest itself in a number of ways, including eating disorders and self-harm behaviours used as a coping mechanism.We know that the negative impact of the lockdowns on children was a major driving factor in reopening schools and keeping them open even as the highly infectious Omicron strain arrived on these shores.But with case rates now so high, when can families and schools expect some respite With , new cases and a further death in a person aged over  recorded yesterday, it is obvious Covid has not disappeared. Yet, Professor Mike Tildesley, an expert in infectious disease modelling at the University of Warwick, is hopeful the situation in schools will begin to improve in the coming weeks.“It’s always hard to predict, but my hope is that we get towards the end of February and start to see cases go down,” he said.However, he warned the removal of other restrictions was likely to result in at least a plateau in the case rate. “The situation is slightly complicated by the end of interventions,” he said.Prof Young is also optimistic that we may soon begin to see a downward trend in case numbers, which will eventually allow more children and teachers toto classes.“We have seen an overall increase in the case numbers of over %, and that’s been largely driven by cases in people aged  and under,” he said.“We have also seen a small increase in adults between  and , and I’m pretty sure those are parents of schoolchildren [because] there is a high risk of household transmission once Covid gets into a household.“There is a secondary peak, and I don’t think we’re over the top yet.“I think that there is a big question over how rapidly it’s going to decline. “It could be relatively slow and, certainly, it could take a number of weeks, but I would expect it to be well declined by Easter.”With Covid expected to continue to circulate at fairly high levels in schools in the coming months, what do the experts believe should be put in place to help alleviate the situation Prof Young said continuing measures such as ventilation, face coverings and vaccination would prove crucial.However, Prof Tildesley said he would like to see face coverings removed from school settings as soon as possible.Meanwhile, Prof O’Neill called for vaccinations to be made available to younger age groups.“There is evidence of increased hospitalisation of children with Covid,” he said.“I’m disappointed that vaccination isn’t available to children, I think, at the very least, there should be that choice so parents can weigh up the benefits versus the risks.”Related topicsDepartment of HealthDepartment of EducationMore On Department of HealthPolitical instability the last thing NI needs, says story: Seamus Leheny, Policy Manager at Logistics UK  FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueSeamus Leheny, Policy Manager at Logistics UK By Rebecca Black, PAFebruary   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailThe Government has been urged to provide clarity following an order from Stormont Agriculture Minister Edwin Poots to stop Brexit checks at Northern Ireland’s ports.Seamus Leheny of Logistics NI said the sector has been plunged into confusion.On Thursday morning lorries were still being received at a Department of Agriculture, Environment and Rural Affairschecking facility in Belfast Port.Lorries, including this consignment of tractors are continuing to arrive at the DAERA facility on Duncrue Street hours after the order by Agriculture Minister Edwin Poots to stop Protocol checks pic MlymdYAuDW— Rebecca BlackFebruary , Mr Leheny said businesses received advice to continue to complete paperwork.“There is a lot of confusion and a lot of anxiety with businesses, they weren’t too sure what they had to do, did they still have to fulfil the administration with regards to moving products of animal origin in here,” he told the PA news agency.“Generally the advice this morning from government departments is that you must still complete the paperwork to move goods in here. I’m not really too sure what is happening at the border control posts, we’ve not been told what is happening yet… but at the moment we have been told to keep doing the customs and keep doing the phytosanitary paperwork.”Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is story: As the Queen’s platinum jubilee nears, NI couple are reminded of their first meetingExpandExpandExpandPreviousNext" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseThe couple todayFond couple todayAmy CochraneTwitterEmailFebruary   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailTwo childhood friends, who met during a street party celebrating the Queen’s coronation in east Belfast in , eventually married one another and are still together after almost  years of marriage.The Queen is celebrating her platinum jubilee this year, with tomorrow marking  years since her accession to the throne.Following the coronation at Westminster Abbey on June , , the Queen made a three-day trip to Northern Ireland in July accompanied by her husband, Prince Philip.Expand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" coronation party in east BelfastRobert and Charlotte Casey were aged just seven and nine when they celebrated the coronation seven decades ago.Robert said it was “one of the happiest memories of my childhood”.Street parties took over the surrounding streets of Parkgate Parade in Sydenham, where Robert lived, and he recalled spending the day playing with his friends and neighbours, which included Charlotte’s cousins.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up “Charlotte lived only a few streets over, I remember I used to carry her schoolbag for her!” he explained.“We were always together, never too far away from one another, even in the photograph we are beside each other.”Robert explained that families who lived along Parkgate would pay weekly to host a street party for the coronation.“It was just a fantastic celebration, I still remember it to this day,” he said.“The coronation was a big thing in those days, we used to be a very tight community in east Belfast.“I remember, where the King George V playing fields are now, it used to be just a stretch of spare ground and we would always play there.”Robert’s father worked at the Harland and Wolff shipyard and a giant arch was created by him and his friends to commemorate the coronation.Expand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseFond memories: Robert and Charlotte Casey on their wedding day specially made aluminium as the road was so wide, he explained that anything heavier would not have been able to stand.Following in his father’s footsteps, Robert went on to work in the shipyard himself until he was  before working for Rolls Royce as an engineer.He stayed on in school until he was , but even though his school was in Belfast, his family moved back to their original home of Moneyreagh, near Ballygowan.Robert went to school in the centre of Belfast and Charlotte went to Ashfield.The pair first became more than friends when they met at a dance hall in Anne Street as teenagers.After she left school Charlotte worked as a beautician in Belfast, and despite Robert’s family moving out of Belfast, the couple still stayed in touch and he would travel on the bus to visit her until he passed his driving test and could eventually drive to meet after school and on the weekends.They eventually married in  and moved to Moneyreagh, where they lived for  years, but are now Credit: Kelvin Boyes   Press Eye FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueThe £ Spend Local cardAmy CochraneTwitterEmailFebruary   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailIt has been revealed that , emails sent by the Department of the Economy to high street voucher cardholders in Northern Ireland in December included the wrong telephone number.They were followed by a further , emails including the correct number the following day, according to Economy Minister Gordon Lyons.The Spend Local scheme was launched by the minister in October .All householders across Northern Ireland were eligible for a pre-paid card to spend in local shops under one of Stormont’s flagship post-Covid economic stimulus policies.By the time applications closed, nearly .m cards had been circulated.Read MoreHigh Street scheme payments to , accounts ‘won’t have to be spent local’The scheme, however, was not without its problems.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up Despite the deadline to use the cards being extended a number of times late last year, some people were not been able to spend the money, because of issues including postage delivery failures, technical problems in activating the cards or administrative mistakes by the Economy Department.A few days before the deadline of December , , the department had sent emails to cardholders asking them to spend the remaining balance on their cards.But the inclusion of the incorrect phone number led to Bangor businesswoman, Helen McMahon, who owns a first aid training company, receiving over , phone calls from members of the public querying issues with their cards.Ulster Unionist MLA Alan Chambers posed a question to the Economy Minister asking whether the owner of the phone number had been in touch with the department and whether any arrangements have been put in place to mitigate the number of calls the owner may receive.Mt Lyons replied to both questions simply ‘yes’.North Down MLA Mr Chambers then followed up with the question asking how many people were sent the email, to which the minister confirmed there were , people who received the email who had above £ in their card balance.Mr Lyons claried in his reply that the last digit of the phone number was incorrect.Mr Chambers said: “It is human error, but you would expect a government department to proof check any information they send out, and in particular a phone number.“My office dealt with a huge number of applicants who missed out on the scheme through no fault of their own.“We have continued to fight their cause and the minister has now introduced a scheme to place £ directly into the bank account of those who lost out.“Hopefully this damage limitation exercise will proceed in a more efficient manner than some other elements of the scheme have been conducted.”It is predicted that around , people will receive £ into their bank accounts who had not received a card.Unlike those who did receive a card, it is understood that there will be no restrictions on where you can spend it.At the end of last month, Mr Lyons announced that his department would spend up to £.m on making the payments to people who didn’t get their cards, or weren’t able to use them properly, through the BACS system of money transfer.The department, which is administering the £m scheme, did not respond when askedthe use of the cash would be limited to spending in bricks and mortar shops. title: stormonts last securi cat enjoying her retirement after being adopted
story: Maggie always put a smile on people’s faces, says former special adviser Expand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeClosePopular: Maggie the Stormont cat FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":truePopular: Maggie the Stormont catConchur DowdsFebruary   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailIn a week full of political departures, the latest long-standing figure to leave Stormont is not another representative or minister, but a cat.While most eyes have been focused on Paul Givan’s resignation and a series of Downing Street civil servants who have quit, it has since come to light that Maggie, the last remaining ‘Stormont cat’ has left the estate.It is understood that Maggie, who is believed to be  or  years old, has been adopted by a civil servant and is now living in the Craigavon area.She is said to be happy and content in her new home.A colony of cats once roamed the Stormont Estate. However, the numbers slowly dwindled, and by  only three remained — Maggie, Ginger and Furby.The trio, nicknamed the ‘securi-cats’ by former Deputy First Minister Martin McGuinness, made the headlines in  after a number of retired civil servants were banned from caring for the animals.Despite having looked out for their furry friends for years and feeding them every day, they were denied access after being deemed a “security risk”.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up Thanks to this newspaper, however, the group soon secured freedom of access to the cats once again.In , Ginger and Furbie died just weeks apart, leaving Maggie alone on the estate for the past few years. As the final Stormont cat finally takes her leave, her departure has been described as the “end of an era.”Maggie is of a similar age to Larry the cat, who has served as ‘chief mouser’ to the Cabinet Office at  Downing Street for the past  years.While she may not share the fame or following of Larry’ssocial media account, Maggie is highly thought of by those who knew her.Peter Cardwell, who previously served as a special adviser to the late Northern Ireland Secretary James Brokenshire, said that seeing Maggie as he walked into work always brightened up his day.He added: “I was a huge fan of the cats. I’m a cat person and I took a real interest in them soon after starting at Stormont House.“I remember Stormont collapsing in early . At that time, it was a very serious job and there weren’t too many laughs for a while. “But just seeing the cats and talking about them, they brought a smile to people’s faces.”“I recall having a conversation with James Brokenshire about the cats which Lord Caine, who had been a special adviser to numerous Northern Ireland Secretaries, was also listening to.“We were walking along a corridor and he said he had learned more about the cats in the last  seconds than he had in all his years at Stormont House.”It is understood that Maggie’s departure comes as the Northern Ireland Office of the civil sex assault case against him.Andrew will face what is known as a deposition on March  in London, in what has been described as a neutral location.A source close to the royal said his and at trial”.The renowned lawyer was listed as one of the  most influential people in the world by Time Magazine in , and he has been named Global International Litigator of the Year by Who’s Who Despite repeated requests, Ms. Giuffre still hasn’t committed to a date or location for her deposition.”Thereported that those due to give depositions after Andrew include the royal’s former assistant, Robert Olney, and Shukri Walker, who claims to have seen Andrew in Tramp nightclub.Last month, court documents revealed that US Judge Lewis A Kaplan had written letters to the Senior Master of the Queen’s Bench Division in the UK to request assistance in acquiring evidence for the civil claim filed by Ms Giuffre.The judge asked for Mr Olney to be quizzed on topics such as Andrew’s communications with Maxwell, Epstein and Ms Giuffre, and his travel to Epstein’s homes.In a separate letter to the High Court, Judge Kaplan also requested testimony from Ms Walker, on questions about the presence of the duke and Ms Giuffre at Tramp nightclub in March  and any interactions the pair had.The civil sex assault trial is scheduled to take place between September and December.The parties will need to confirm by July  whether they wish to proceed to trial.
